 Good point, stormboy. That statement, as simple as it sounds, is the key. However, it’s like hauling hay in the middle of summer for some folks, and for others, a walk in the park. What separates the two mindsets? What causes one person to dread it and the other to cheerfully welcome it? I think belief is the main factor. But, how can one acquire belief just for the purpose of discovery? Even for just a glimpse? For meager consideration?
 
 Prayer works for everyone and is indiscriminate.

 I understand. But, those contradictions can be picked clean.

 I know I'm bad about hijacking, Joe, and I appologize to stormboy and to you, but I really hate religion in that respect - how it misleads its followers; how it corrupts the Bible and how it "speaks" for God. Sure, it's based on denomination and divisions. But, the fact still remains that it's up to the person to ask for help in even the most (seemingly) simple verses. I'm not going to dispute that the wording and interpretations are askew. It's evident. What I am disputing is you or I taking someone else's word for it.

 What is funny is we are not going to debate well with each other becuase I agree with you. I just don't like it when people use the supernatural force of the holy spirit to defend the bible. Really I find it silly. The start of this thread makes a very interesting analogy about the roadmap to god. When someone asked how do you know it the word of god, the reply says "because it lead me to god". That is a lame answer really. That is all it takes to convince someone that the bible is the word of god, because it made you feel better. With that logic, as soon as a drug makes someone feel than that drug must be the cure for cancer. If that is all the evidence needed. My cancer is cured.

Jefferson may have been onto something here. . . ."Fix reason firmly in her seat, and call to her tribunal every fact, every opinion. Question with boldness even the existence of a god; because, if there be one, he must approve the homage of reason rather than of blind-folded fear. Do not be frightened from this inquiry by any fear of its consequences.... If it end in a belief that there is no god, you will find incitements to virtue in the comfort and pleasantness you feel in its exercise and in the love of others it will procure for you."-- Thomas Jefferson, to Peter Carr, 10 Aug. 1787. (original capitalization of the word god is retained per original)

The Word of God is a roadmap to Hell.

 
 Indeed. I hold these truths to be self-evident and undeniable: all religions are man-made and self-centered (gimme prayers), self-seeking ("eternal life"), and self-glorifying (a shining soul). They all promise those who accept their dogmas "life everlasting." They are all belief systems that deny death. All require belief in a magical transition to a paradise after death, besides believing in imaginary, invisible deities with whom they can talk directly.
 
 In a hospital, a person who believes in and talks to imaginary beings is considered mentally ill. Religious beliefs are a form of mental illness. Organized religion is the most dangerous, divisive, and destructive force in the world.

 hundreds of millions of people are united in their faith be it Christians, Muslims, whatever
 
 the world exists only in your mind therefore you have no proof that everything you think it is real it exists independently, outside you. You could well be imagining everthing and you would never know otherwise. 
 
 
 "When I consider the fact that I have doubts, or that I am a thing that is incomplete and dependent, then there arises in me a clear and distinct idea of a being who is independent and complete, that is, an idea of God. And from the mere fact that there is such an idea within me, or that I who possess this idea exist, I clearly infer that God exists, and that every single moment of my entire existence depends on him ... And now, from this contemplation of the true God, in whom all the treasures of wisdom and the sciences, lie hidden, I think I can see a way forward to the knowledge of other things" (Descartes)

how do you know that the bible, or any holy book is actually the word of God?

 
 The MORE you study the WORD OF GOD, the closer you'll get to GOD and the better you'll be at knowing the TRUTH. Just as Christ taught in PARABLES, there are passages that AREN'T recorded/translated correctly, but can be understood correctly by those that KNOW GOD. 
 
 Just as you know the TRUE MEANING of someone you know well (your parents) but may NOT UNDERSTAND the TRUE MEANING of the slang used by a visitor in your town.
